attachments.title: SXSWedu 2017, PanelPicker, Meet Ups and London
attachments.text: Like many of you, the SXSWedu team is busy digesting the amazing event that took place this March in Austin, Texas. Over the next couple of weeks, we'll be reviewing all of the feedback from folks who attended and participated in the event. This feedback is vital and will help us continue to improve the SXSWedu experience for all as we move forward. Many of you have reached out with inquiries for 2017 ... we are thrilled to see enthusiasm for the event, it's never too early to start thinking about what's next! So with that in mind, here are a few things to put on your radar:
attachments.fallback: SXSWedu.com: SXSWedu 2017, PanelPicker, Meet Ups and London

text: Hi All, reorganized and updated the todo file. Should give you a clear indication of what my next round of features will entail
where can I find the call?
Hi guys
<@U0D6EPESC> Phew, that Simple vs. Easy talk is quite technical...

My feedback:
Overall I like the more collaborative, almost playful, vibe to the app. But the experience ended up to be a bit confusing. Everything feels a bit out of place and the iconography isn’t immediately clear. More specifically I noticed these things:

1. The task list is in a weird place. It’s intuitively the main thing of a goal and yet it’s hidden at the bottom.
2. Hierarchy is a problem. In the goal and task view the actual goal or task has less visual space and weight than the collaborative features. It should be more equal.
3. WIP—submit and goal discussion seem overlapping features somehow.  I’d opt for the latter, incase multiple people encounter the same problem. 
4. The graph feels pushy, not constructive and a big temptation to exploit. Being S.M.A.R.T. is cool to get started and get stuff done, but learning isn’t this measurable in the end. The app shouldn’t give the illusion that it is. 

One more small thing: The user modal shouldn’t link do dashboard but just disappear.
ah, yes, forgot about that. Just check on multiple devices
Hey guys, you realize  that it's a tablet app.

I don't see where I can create content. Only to suggest alternative resources (links).

Navigation issues:

- On my iPhone:
  - the opening page shows one goal. It's not clear that I should scroll right to see the other goals.
  - I can't see the bottom of the progress bar graph
  - I can't scroll through the task list and can only see the first three tasks

- On my laptop:
  - When I first click on a goal, I see stats on how others are doing, the discussions and work in progress, but it's unclear to me what to do or how to get started myself. The bar at the bottom doesn't draw enough attention to help me find my way.

General:
- I feel a need for more descriptive feedback from the interface, telling me what I'm seeing
- Does the landing page lists all the goals I'm working on? Or also other goals?
- What's the dashed line in the progress bar graph?Is that where am I? Does the height correspond with how many tasks I've done? 
- It looks and feels like many other apps. There's little that sets it apart.
My feedback on the Lifely CtH demo:

files.name: -.txt
files.title: Untitled
files.preview:
Hi all, here's my feedback on Lifely's prototype:

- Where’s the sample course? 
- Social is very prominent, while the tasks disappear in the bottom of the screen, while the latter should be leading in the platform
- The feedback-function is hidden below the Submit work button. I’d only click ‘Submit’ if I were to hand in something finished, not use that for getting feedback

attachments.title: Simple Made Easy
attachments.text: Rich Hickey emphasizes simplicity’s virtues over easiness’, showing that while many choose easiness they may end up with complexity, and the better way is to choose easiness along the simplicity path.

text: <@U0D6EPESC> I didn't know that. And as an aside: I want to attend either SXSW/Austin sometime anyway and if it's such a networking event, even the better. But I don't think March. We still need to work on our story and preferably practice that story at lesser events and work towards getting a shot talking to people at such a big conference. You're working your ass off to code the whole thing on your own, we aren't working our asses off enough to have an online presence that could support us networking there... I think its too soon. That realisation, however, is a wake up call. That big project meeting we've been planning is a few weeks overdue and I'm ready to commit to getting us where we need to be on the comms side of things, especially knowing that Greg's going to be less available, which is completely fine of(f)course. Got some ideas and examples there that I'm going to share in a minute too.
<@U0ARRNM3R> I agree with your opinion in general, but sxsw is known to be a networking / funding event. Not only for speakers. I think we should seriously consider it...

They have an EDU special? Awesome. (Yes, this too.) Apparently it's every year. How have we not heard of this before? But: I do believe that our attending conferences days are behind us and we should aim to speak at them instead. As an attendee, you're just the so-maniest person who wants to make it. And we've been that person on so many events already, and I honestly don't think it's worth the investment right now/anymore. As a speaker, however, or even as a volunteer in my experience, you get *so much more* traction. OK, this might be a big one, but there are so many events that we can start to make appearances. (Also, it's in March, and we're moving.) I clicked a bit on the site, though, and they  also have a yearly Startup competition (although the word startup really makes me feel disgustingly pathetic lately). Application is closed, but this is something to track and possibly even work towards for next year. I mean, if we can present your Ed Startup at SXSW, we're AWESOME in all caps.
this particular SXSW seems like it’d be a good place to network, or maybe even pitch/share depending on what stage OC is at at that point in time
Hey guys, should not we go here? <http://sxswedu.com/> <!channel>

Hi <!channel>!

Here are some notes on our last call. We talked about the blog and funding. There are some questions left to answer, they are marked ><:

Blog
- we proposed to start a joint blog under Unacademic, comparable to A List Apart or Smashing Magazine, with a general topic with varied posts by a multitude of (guest) authors 
- every author has their own page, for example greg.unacademic.io, so you can link to it from your own website and/or social media
- we can benefit from each others traffic
- it’s not a blog about Offcourse, but we can introduce Offcourse when we want 
- a lot of plusses, but it *is* an extra space to maintain and update on a regular basis
- we need to think about the general topic/mission statement to give the blog some direction

>>and do we still want a marketing website for Offcourse?< 

Funding
We found a possible (small) funding/training opportunity: http://ece.nl/programme/getstarted. Is it a fit?

>>if yes, who would like to apply?<

About the big-picture call, we really would like Reika to be able to join us, so we want to wait until she’s available and/or back from the States. Not to join the team if she’s not ready, but to participate in defining the direction for Offcourse in 2016. 

@Reika, would you like to join and if yes, when are you available?

Have a good New Year’s Eve!
Merry Xmas everyone! Hope you're having a great day, wherever you are! :smile::wine_glass:

Hi <!channel>: tonight's call will just be <@U0CRWKV2T> and <@U0D6EPESC>. They need some time to discuss the next blog post. Next week, we want to discuss the big picture of Offcourse. If at all possible, we'd love for <@U0ARUBWPK> to join us then. Would you be available?
<@U0D6EPESC>: Wow, interesting opportunity, the SWEDU. Lot of work though. Let's discuss next week?

text:
Hey <!everyone>, you probably saw this in the national newsletter, but wanted to catch your attention here too, especially since I thought some of you would be interested directly, or might otherwise know someone who could be down for these opportunities: 

We just opened our application process for our Community Catalyst Program (CCP) and for organizers of Startup Weekend Education (SWEDU) and I need 30 seconds of your help. For both programs, we’re looking for amazing people who want to build education entrepreneurship communities where they live, either to run a single event like a SWEDU or commit to community building full time through CCP. The deadline for Community Catalyst Applications is January 7th and the priority deadline for SWEDU organizers is also January 7th.

If you know someone, anyone who might be a good candidate, or any organizations you think we should connect with, just direct message me!

<http://4pt0.org/programs/communitycatalysts/>
The Community Catalyst Program is a is a year-long opportunity that supports leaders coaching, connections and resources someone needs to build and sustain an education entrepreneurship community in their hometown. Specifically, they’ll learn how to coach entrepreneurs and run events/programs that grow the education entrepreneurship community locally. 

<http://4pt0.org/programs/startup-weekend-education/>
Startup Weekend Education is a 54 hour event bringing together passionate educators, entrepreneurs, developers and designers to help design and produce viable products, services, and school models that solve some of education’s most pressing problems. SWEDU organizers 
are in charge of the event and making sure that every participant has a powerful experience. From recruiting judges and mentors to getting space and sponsors, they are the engine that makes the weekend happen.

To share via Twitter: tweet <http://ctt.ec/3dS1c> OR retweet <https://twitter.com/davidthefu/status/674636018230906881>
Interesting to us?
